column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Help a Suicidal Child
#Text=Children and adolescents may not always know how to articulate what they 're feeling inside , which means they may have trouble asking for help when they need it .
#Text=If you think a child is suicidal , the most important thing you can do is to take it seriously .
#Text=Take precautions to keep them safe and get them professional help .
#Text=After setting them up with a professional , be supportive and suggest constructive activities that help them feel better .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Reacting to Suicidal Behavior
#Text=Know the warning signs of suicidal behavior .
#Text=Most youth demonstrate some red flags in their behavior that indicate they are considering suicide .
#Text=A sense of hopelessness about the future and comments or plans pertaining to suicide are often clear indicators .
#Text=However , other warning signs may include :
#Text=Experiencing changes in sleep or eating habits
#Text=Withdrawing from friends and family , spending more time alone
#Text=Displaying acting out or angry behaviors
#Text=Take threats seriously .
#Text=If you spot any of these warning signs in a child , take action immediately .
#Text=Come straight out and ask them if they are feeling suicidal or thinking of hurting themself .
#Text=Some people think a child may say things like , " I do n't want to live anymore " or " Everyone would be better off if I were dead " to get attention .
#Text=Such threats are often cries for help from adolescents who do n't know how to cope with what they are feeling , and these types of statements should be taken seriously .
#Text=Never ignore threats or warning signs that a child is feeling suicidal .
#Text=Do n't leave a suicidal child alone .
#Text=If you suspect a child is suicidal , stay with them .
#Text=Make sure that they are with someone around the clock until the threat passes , or until they are able to seek professional help .
#Text=Remove any weapons or drugs .
#Text=Check the environment for any knives , guns , narcotic medications , or anything else that can be used as a weapon .
#Text=Lock these items away so the child cannot use them to hurt themself .
#Text=Get them to a professional as soon as possible .
#Text=Most suicidal youth have an untreated psychiatric disorder such as depression .
#Text=Have the child seen by a professional therapist who can help alleviate symptoms of depression and get to the root of the issue .
#Text=The child may require therapy and/or medications , depending on the underlying cause .
#Text=In the meantime , the therapist will likely create a safety plan for the child , which includes contact numbers and resources they can access if they feel suicidal .
#Text=Offering Support
#Text=Encourage them to talk .
#Text=The child may feel better if they talk about the thoughts and feelings they are having .
#Text=Ask , “ Do you want to talk about it ? "
#Text=These comments can come off as judgmental and critical .
#Text=Simply be there and allow them to share their feelings .
#Text=Show empathy for what they 're feeling .
#Text=Rather than criticizing them , be empathetic and compassionate .
#Text=Let the child know that you understand where they are coming from .
#Text=This might sound like , " I can see that you have been dealing with this for a while " or " It seems like you 've been very overwhelmed . "
#Text=Attend a support group together .
#Text=Help the child overcome suicidal thoughts and feel less alone in what they 're going through .
#Text=You can do this by accompanying them to a suicide support group for youth .
#Text=These groups offer practical strategies for dealing with upsetting thoughts and feelings as well as support and encouragement .
#Text=Ask the child 's therapist to recommend support groups in your area .
#Text=Improving Their Outlook
#Text=Exercise with them to brighten their mood .
#Text=Physical activity releases feel-good chemicals called endorphins .
#Text=Endorphins can help the child feel more energetic and have a more positive outlook .
#Text=Try exercising for at least 30 minutes each day .
#Text=By exercising with them , you 'll help them engage socially and make sure they are doing something good for their bodies .
#Text=Consider going for a walk around the neighborhood , shooting hoops , or going for a swim .
#Text=Encourage them to spend time doing things they enjoy .
#Text=Drive a budding photographer to a beautiful landscape for pictures .
#Text=Purchase lessons for a child who is interested in guitar or piano .
#Text=Hobbies and passions can help the child feel better about life and remember things they are good at .
#Text=Work with them to pare down their responsibilities .
#Text=The child may be stressed out due to demanding school work and extracurricular activities .
#Text=Sit down with them and look at their schedule .
#Text=Are they over-committing ?
#Text=If so , help them trim down their weekly routine so that they have a more balanced , realistic schedule .
#Text=Encourage social activities over solo ones .
#Text=Suicidal children may be more likely to pull away from others and spend time alone .
#Text=Stress the importance of social engagement and provide opportunities for them to spend time with friends and family .
#Text=Host a BBQ and invite kids from school or the neighborhood , or plan a family movie or game night .
#Text=You might also encourage the child to join new clubs or organizations at school so they can make new friends .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=While there are things you can do to help and support your child , remember that nobody can entirely prevent suicide .
#Text=You cannot control your child ’s thoughts or actions .
#Text=What you can do is be supportive and encouraging , give them the help and resources they need to get better , and let them know that you are there for them .
